title: 112_s3485
content: The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Simplification Act of 2012" limits state withholding and taxation of employee income. The "Mobile Workforce State Income Tax Simplification Act of 2012" restricts state income tax withholding and reporting for employees working in multiple states. Wages earned by an employee in multiple states are only subject to income tax in their state of residence and the state where they work for more than 30 days in a calendar year. Income tax withholding and reporting requirements apply from the start of employment duties in the state. The employer can rely on an employee's determination of time spent working in different states for tax purposes, as long as there is no fraud or collusion. Maintaining records of an employee's location does not override the employee's determination. The employer can rely on an employee's determination of time spent working in different states for tax purposes, as long as there is no fraud or collusion. If the employer maintains a time and attendance system tracking where the employee works daily, that data will be used instead of the employee's determination. Definitions and special rules apply, such as considering an employee present in a state if they perform more duties there than in any other state during a day. For tax purposes, an employee's work location in different states can be determined by the employer or the employee, with special rules applying. The term "employee" excludes professional athletes, entertainers, and certain public figures. The curr_chunk defines professional athletes, entertainers, and certain public figures as individuals who perform services for wages or other remuneration on a per-event basis in their respective capacities. The curr_chunk defines professional athletes, entertainers, and certain public figures as individuals who perform services for wages or other remuneration on a per-event basis, provided that the wages are for services at a discrete event like a speech or public appearance. The term "employer" is defined as per the Internal Revenue Code, unless defined differently by the State where the employee works. The term "State" refers to any of the several States. The term "time and attendance system" is a system where the employee records their work location daily. The term "wages or other remuneration" may be limited by the State where employment duties are performed, and a time and attendance system must record work location daily for employees working outside their primary State. The Act will take effect on January 1 of the 2nd year after enactment and will not apply to any tax obligations before that date.
